title: Routing the Lottery: Adaptive Subnetworks for Heterogeneous Data
summary: This paper introduces Routing the Lottery (RTL), an adaptive pruning framework that generates multiple specialized subnetworks, or 'adaptive tickets', tailored to specific classes, semantic clusters, or conditions within heterogeneous datasets. RTL consistently outperforms traditional single and multi-model baselines in accuracy and recall, while drastically reducing parameter count, offering a novel approach to align model structure with inherent data diversity.

title: Early and Prediagnostic Detection of Pancreatic Cancer from Computed Tomography
summary: This paper introduces ePAI, an artificial intelligence system designed for the early and prediagnostic detection of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) from computed tomography (CT) scans. ePAI demonstrated high accuracy and sensitivity in both internal and external validations, crucially detecting lesions up to 36 months before clinical diagnosis, often overlooked by radiologists. A multi-reader study confirmed ePAI's significant outperformance of board-certified radiologists in sensitivity for early PDAC detection.

title: The Patient is not a Moving Document: A World Model Training Paradigm for Longitudinal EHR
summary: This paper introduces SMB-Structure, a novel 'world model' paradigm for structured Electronic Health Records (EHR) that simulates patient dynamics rather than merely predicting next tokens. By integrating a Joint-Embedding Prediction Architecture (JEPA) with next-token prediction (SFT), the model learns embeddings that capture disease trajectories, outperforming autoregressive baselines and achieving competitive performance on complex tasks in large oncology and pulmonary embolism cohorts.

title: BioAgent Bench: An AI Agent Evaluation Suite for Bioinformatics
summary: This paper introduces BioAgent Bench, a novel evaluation suite and benchmark dataset for systematically measuring the performance and robustness of AI agents in complex, end-to-end bioinformatics tasks. It evaluates both closed-source and open-weight models, revealing that while agents can construct high-level pipelines, they often fail under controlled perturbations, underscoring critical weaknesses in step-level reasoning. The research also highlights the crucial trade-off between model performance and data privacy, advocating for open-weight models in sensitive clinical contexts despite lower completion rates.

title: Temporal Sepsis Modeling: a Fully Interpretable Relational Way
summary: This paper introduces a novel machine learning framework for temporal sepsis modeling that prioritizes extreme interpretability, addressing the limitations of existing deep learning models which often lack transparency. It proposes a relational approach to process temporal electronic medical record (EMR) data, constructing interpretable features via a propositionalisation technique, and classifying them using a selective Naive Bayesian classifier. The framework's relevance and comprehensive fourfold interpretability (univariate, global, local, and counterfactual) are demonstrated through experimental validation.

title: Impact of behavioral heterogeneity on epidemic outcome and its mapping into effective network topologies
summary: Human behavior plays a critical role in shaping epidemic trajectories. During health crises, people respond in diverse ways in terms of self-protection and adherence to recommended measures, largely reflecting differences in how individuals assess risk. This behavioral variability induces effective ...

title: Independent Component Discovery in Temporal Count Data
summary: Advances in data collection are producing growing volumes of temporal count observations, making adapted modeling increasingly necessary. In this work, we introduce a generative framework for independent component analysis of temporal count data, combining regime-adaptive dynamics with Poisson log-n...

title: Multimodal Visual Surrogate Compression for Alzheimer's Disease Classification
summary: This paper introduces Multimodal Visual Surrogate Compression (MVSC), a novel method for Alzheimer's Disease (AD) classification using structural MRI (sMRI) images. MVSC compresses high-dimensional 3D sMRI volumes into compact 2D features, termed visual surrogates, which are then optimally processed by frozen 2D foundation models to extract powerful representations. The method addresses existing challenges in AD diagnosis by enhancing computational efficiency, preserving cross-slice context, and improving feature discriminability, demonstrating favorable performance on multiple large-scale AD benchmarks.

title: When Gradient Optimization Is Not Enough: $\dagger$ Dispersive and Anchoring Geometric Regularizer for Multimodal Learning
summary: Multimodal learning often struggles with 'geometric pathologies' like intra-modal representation collapse and sample-level cross-modal inconsistency, even with advanced optimization, hindering robust fusion. This paper introduces \regName, a lightweight, plug-and-play geometric regularization framework, which enforces intra-modal dispersive regularization for diversity and inter-modal anchoring regularization to bound cross-modal drift. Extensive experiments demonstrate consistent improvements in both multimodal and unimodal performance, effectively mitigating modality trade-offs by explicitly structuring representation geometry.

title: Expected Return Causes Outcome-Level Mode Collapse in Reinforcement Learning and How to Fix It with Inverse Probability Scaling
summary: This paper identifies outcome-level mode collapse in reinforcement learning (RL), where policies converge to a narrow subset of high-quality solutions, as a structural consequence of the expected-return objective itself, rather than solely exploration issues. It proposes Inverse Probability Scaling (IPS) as a minimal correction that fundamentally alters learning dynamics to yield reward-proportional terminal distributions, preventing collapse, and demonstrates its effectiveness in tasks including molecular generation.

title: Computational investigation of single herbal drugs in Ayurveda for diabetes and obesity using knowledge graph and network pharmacology
summary: This paper presents an integrated computational pipeline leveraging knowledge graphs, pathway analysis, and network pharmacology to elucidate the multi-target mechanisms of Ayurvedic Single Herbal Drugs (SHDs) for type 2 diabetes and obesity. It successfully identified key disease-relevant targets, synergistic phytochemical interactions, and putative lead compounds, thereby providing a scientific basis for the multi-faceted action of these traditional medicines.

title: PathReasoner-R1: Instilling Structured Reasoning into Pathology Vision-Language Model via Knowledge-Guided Policy Optimization
summary: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) are advancing computational pathology with superior visual understanding capabilities. However, current systems often reduce diagnosis to directly output conclusions without verifiable evidence-linked reasoning, which severely limits clinical trust and hinders expert er...
